misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that elements of a String array might remain null or revert to null even after a loop has explicitly assigned every element a value (either from input or an empty string literal).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's execution model, once an array element is assigned a reference (like a String object), that reference remains until explicitly changed. String arrays are initialized with nulls, but if every index is visited and assigned in a loop, no nulls will remain. Furthermore, Scanner.next() never returns null; it either returns a String or throws an exception.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the Scanner is context-aware and can distinguish between different logical 'sections' of input (like names vs. scores). They believe that checking hasNext() and hasNextInt() in separate loops will prevent cross-contamination of data types.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Scanner treats the input as a flat, linear stream of tokens. sc.next() consumes the very next token regardless of whether the programmer intended it to be a name or a score. If the user provides fewer names than N, the Scanner will simply consume the first few scores as names, as it has no concept of the 'category' of the token beyond its basic format.
